channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: More Clashes In Pakistan As Pressure On Government Grows
item.description: Anti-government protesters in Pakistan briefly forced state TV off the air amid continuing clashes with police and renewed calls for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's resignation.
item.content:encoded:
Anti-government protesters in Pakistan briefly forced state TV off the air amid continuing clashes with police and renewed calls for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's resignation.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Krishnadev Calamur

item.title: Ahead Of New Talks, Russian Minister Calls For Ukraine Cease-Fire
item.description: Russian and Ukrainian officials are meeting today with Russia-backed separatists and international monitors, but the sides remain far apart and the fighting continues in the eastern part of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
Russian and Ukrainian officials are meeting today with Russia-backed separatists and international monitors, but the sides remain far apart and the fighting continues in the eastern part of Ukraine.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Krishnadev Calamur

item.title: Volunteer Docs In Peru Take A Shopping Trip To Look For Patients
item.description: The medical students were in Iquitos. They could provide much-needed surgery for the residents of this remote Peruvian town. Just one problem: They didn't have enough patients.
item.content:encoded:
The medical students were in Iquitos. They could provide much-needed surgery for the residents of this remote Peruvian town. Just one problem: They didn't have enough patients.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Dave Ohlson

item.title: Why Did Crowd Flee Shanghai Subway After Foreigner Fainted?
item.description: A widely-watched video shows a foreigner fainting on a subway car and everyone around him fleeing. No one helps. It's rekindled a national debate about trust, fear and the Chinese national character.
item.content:encoded:
A widely-watched video shows a foreigner fainting on a subway car and everyone around him fleeing. No one helps. It's rekindled a national debate about trust, fear and the Chinese national character.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Frank Langfitt

item.title: Protesters Demand Pakistani Prime Minister Sharif's Ouster
item.description: Protesters surrounded Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's home, and for a brief period forced government TV off the air. Steve Inskeep talks to Jon Boone, a correspondent for The Guardian in Islamabad.
item.content:encoded:
Protesters surrounded Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's home, and for a brief period forced government TV off the air. Steve Inskeep talks to Jon Boone, a correspondent for The Guardian in Islamabad.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Senegal Is Fifth West African Nation Hit With Ebola
item.description: A Guinean student in the Senegalese capital of Dakar has tested positive for the deadly disease. David Greene talks to Krista Larson, West Africa correspondent for the Associated Press.
item.content:encoded:
A Guinean student in the Senegalese capital of Dakar has tested positive for the deadly disease. David Greene talks to Krista Larson, West Africa correspondent for the Associated Press.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Amazon's German Workers Push For Higher Wages, Union Contract
item.description: Amazon has thousands of workers in Germany and many are unhappy that they're classified as lower-paid logistics workers. The company says they're well compensated for unskilled labor.
item.content:encoded:
Amazon has thousands of workers in Germany and many are unhappy that they're classified as lower-paid logistics workers. The company says they're well compensated for unskilled labor.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ross Reynolds

item.title: Islamic State Suffers Rare Defeat In Amerli
item.description: On Sunday, Iraqi and Kurdish forces broke a nearly 80-day siege by the Islamic State on the town of Amerli, where residents now have enough food and water for the first time in weeks.
item.content:encoded:
On Sunday, Iraqi and Kurdish forces broke a nearly 80-day siege by the Islamic State on the town of Amerli, where residents now have enough food and water for the first time in weeks.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Peter Kenyon

item.title: 'Lady Al-Qaida' And The Business Of Prisoner Swaps
item.description: Arun Rath talks to journalist Shane Harris about his Foreign Policy story on "Lady al-Qaida," Aafia Siddiqui. The Pakistani-born woman was arrested in Afghanistan in 2008.
item.content:encoded:
Arun Rath talks to journalist Shane Harris about his Foreign Policy story on "Lady al-Qaida," Aafia Siddiqui. The Pakistani-born woman was arrested in Afghanistan in 2008.

» E-Mail This

item.title: PTSD Goes Largely Untreated In Iraq's Kurdish Region
item.description: The U.S. military's attention to PTSD is well-documented but Kurdish fighters living with the same disorder haven't received nearly as much care. Arun Rath talks to journalist Jenna Krajeski.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. military's attention to PTSD is well-documented but Kurdish fighters living with the same disorder haven't received nearly as much care. Arun Rath talks to journalist Jenna Krajeski.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Guantanamo Defense Lawyer Resigns, Says U.S. Case Is 'Stacked'
item.description: One of the lawyers for self-proclaimed Sept. 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed resigned from the Army last week. He tells NPR the government is putting on a "show trial."
item.content:encoded:
One of the lawyers for self-proclaimed Sept. 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed resigned from the Army last week. He tells NPR the government is putting on a "show trial."

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Gaza's Shattered Airport, Once A Symbol Of Sovereignty
item.description: The sad spectacle of Gaza's bombed-out airport doesn't deter Palestinians from hoping to someday have another airport of their own.
item.content:encoded:
The sad spectacle of Gaza's bombed-out airport doesn't deter Palestinians from hoping to someday have another airport of their own.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Philip Reeves

item.title: Rebels Reportedly Seize Part Of U.S. Embassy Compound In Tripoli
item.description: A YouTube video shows a large group of men occupying a building that the U.S. ambassador to Libya says appears to be the embassy's residential annex.
item.content:encoded:
A YouTube video shows a large group of men occupying a building that the U.S. ambassador to Libya says appears to be the embassy's residential annex.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Hong Kong Activists Protest China's Control Of Leadership Vote
item.description: People in the former British colony are angered that a vote for the territory's next chief executive will be from a list of candidates hand-pickled by Beijing.
item.content:encoded:
People in the former British colony are angered that a vote for the territory's next chief executive will be from a list of candidates hand-pickled by Beijing.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Putin Calls For Talks To Consider Statehood For Southeastern Ukraine
item.description: The Russian leader said "substantive, meaningful talks" were needed to decide the outcome in the region, while a spokesman clarified that the region should remain part of Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
The Russian leader said "substantive, meaningful talks" were needed to decide the outcome in the region, while a spokesman clarified that the region should remain part of Ukraine.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman
